revision.text:
'''<<< [[Circuit Idea#Table of Contents|contents]] - [[Circuit Idea/How do We Create Sinusoidal Oscillations?|LC tank]] - page stage {{stage short|50%}} >>>'''
----
'''Comparing the Ideas behind Relaxation and LC Oscillators'''
== A relaxation oscillator == '''The basic idea.''' The simpler and more intuitive '''relaxation oscillator''' consists of (Fig. 1) a flow (current) source, an accumulator of potential energy (a capacitor), a switch SW and a load (a resistor)[[Circuit Idea/How to Make the Voltage across a Capacitor Wiggle|How to Make the Voltage across a Capacitor Wiggle]] (creating a philosophy of the relaxation oscillator). Such an arrangement operates in two stages as follows: in the first stage, we connect the current source to the accumulator and begin charging it; in the second stage, we connect the accumulator to the load (turn on the switch SW) and discharge it. Let's repeat it in other words: in a period of a relaxation oscillation, we first draw a kind of energy (usually, potential) from the flow source to fill the accumulator, then "suck dry" the energy from the accumulator and just "throw out" it to the environment. Thus, in the first stage of every period the source has to restore the energy in the accumulator. [[Image:Relaxation_oscillator_1000.jpg|right|thumb|550px|
Fig. 1. A relaxation oscillator has only one accumulating element; the energy moves only in one direction.
]] '''Features.''' Note that the relaxation arrangement needs only one accumulator. It lies on the way of energy and serves as a buffer that interrupts temporarily the flow (only, the average flow remains constant). In this way, it intermits, tears to "pieces" the energy flow. It is interesting fact that a continuous current enters the accumulator while an intermittent current leaves it; so, we might say that a relaxation oscillator "discretisizes", "portens", "doses" the unceasing input flow of energy. At the same time, the accumulator's contents increases and decreases periodically. The shape of the curve is not sinusoidal because at the points of switching (at the peaks) the "flow-creating" quantity has a maximum magnitude. Note also that increase and decrease can have different durations. Examples of this possibility are a photoflash (slow charging, fast discharging), a toilet tank, a husband that fills slowly and continuously a family money deposit while his wife empties rapidly and regularly it:) == An LC oscillator == '''The basic idea.''' Contrary, in order to create an ideal LC oscillation (assume an LC tank without losses), we charge the accumulator only once in the beginning (by turning on the switch SW on the bottom of the figure). Then, we "suck dry" the energy from the accumulator but do not "throw it away"; instead, we convert it into an opposite kind (''kinetic to potential'' or ''potential to kinetic'') and store the converted energy in another accumulator. We move, transfer, convey the energy from the one accumulator to the other. After, we use this energy to restore the energy of the first accumulator instead to "suck" energy from the source (we move back the energy). [[Image:LC_oscillator_1000.jpg|right|thumb|550px|
Fig. 2. An LC oscillator has two accumulating elements; the energy circulates between them.
]] '''Implementation.''' For this purpose, the LC arrangement consists of two heterogeneous (regarding to the two kinds of energy) accumulating elements (Fig. 2). Each of them can either provide energy (when it serves as a source) or store the energy (when it serves as a load). When act as a source, it is a weakening, depleting, exhausting source because the other (accumulating) element "sucks out" the source's energy. The energy moves from the source to the accumulator and the source's output quantity decreases.
== Relaxation versus LC oscillators == === Similarities === #Both the oscillating circuits contain at least one accumulating element that acts either as a source or as an integrator. === Differences === #A relaxation oscillator consists of only one accumulating element while an LC oscillator consists of two accumulating elements. #The relaxation accumulator is ''flow'' or ''pressure'' like; the LC accumulators are heterogeneous (the one is ''flow-like'' and the other is ''pressure-like''). #A relaxation oscillator stores only one kind of energy (usually potential) in the accumulator while an LC oscillator stores two opposite kinds of energy (''kinetic'' and ''potential'') in the two accumulators. #In a relaxation oscillator we "throw away" the energy while in an LC oscillator we treasure it temporarily in an additional accumulator with the purpose of future usage. That's why, LC oscillators are more economical than relaxation ones. #Resonance phenomenon does not exist in a relaxation circuit; it can be observed only in the LC tank. #In a relaxation oscillator the energy moves only in one direction (source -> accumulator -> load) while in an LC oscillator the energy changes periodically its direction (it circulates between the two elements). #The shape of a relaxation oscillation is peaked, angular while the shape of an LC oscillation is rounded (sinusoidal). The reason of that is that at the peaks the source of a relaxation oscillator changes its output quantity with the maximum magnitude while the "source" of an LC oscillator (charged accumulator) does not change its output quantity. #The shape of the relaxation oscillation can be asymmetrical (the increase and the decrease can have different durations) while the shape of the LC oscillation is precisely symmetrical. == References == ----
'''<<< [[#top|top]] - [[Circuit Idea#Table of Contents|contents]] - [[Circuit Idea/How do We Create Sinusoidal Oscillations?|LC tank]] - page stage {{stage short|50%}} >>>'''
[[Category:{{FULLBOOKNAME}}|{{FULLCHAPTERNAME}}]]

<noinclude> <center>'''Street Light Interference'''</center> ---- </noinclude> '''Street light interference''', or '''SLI''', is a phenomenon where people inadvertantly trip the daylight sensors on daylight-sensing light fixtures. People who experience this phenomenon notice it occurring on certain lights- for example, in a parking lot with over a dozen light fixtures, there may be one that will turn on and off when the subject is close to it. This particular light fixture will act strangley, while every other one in the parking lot will remain on.
This phenomenon is similar to psychokenisis, however, one major tenent of it is that the subject cannot control it. Many SLIders (as the subjects are called) do report that the phenomenon occurs more frequently when they are in a heightened emotional state.
Much of the research in this area can be attributed to Hilary Evans, who authored a book, [http://www.assap.org/newsite/Docs/sli.pdf The SLI Effect]. The causes of this phenomenon have yet to be determined; however, surveying has created a statistical analysis of what the phenomenon encompasses.
Critics usually attribute the phenomenon to two things. First, the lights are simply shutting off for explainable reasons- for example, sodium vapor type lamps will blink on and off when they start to fail, as they have experience voltage spikes. Second, due to observer bias, the SLIder notices the light turning off (or on), while they pay no attention to lights that are operating normally. SLIders have attempted to rebuke these through demonstration; however, as yet, no one has been able to cause interference during a demonstration.
<noinclude> ==Media== <center> <gallery caption="Videos by SLIder Doug Coldwell"> Image:Street Light Interference off.ogg|Light shutting off Image:Street Light Interference on.ogg|Light turning itself back on Image:Street Light Interference on and off.ogg|Light cycling </gallery> </center> </noinclude>
{{BookCat}}

revision.comment: /* What the secret of relaxation oscillations is */
revision.text:
''(I would like to start the discussion about relaxation oscillations by moving here the text below from the [[Circuit Idea/How do We Create Sinusoidal Oscillations?|page about LC tank]])'' [[User:Circuit-fantasist|Circuit-fantasist]] ([[User talk:Circuit-fantasist|talk]]) 18:31, 24 January 2008 (UTC)
== What the secret of relaxation oscillations is ==
Maybe, we have first to say here ''what the truth about relaxation oscillation is'' and then to discuss how to present this wisdom to visitors (these are different things). Well, let's begin with the first.
=== The initial point: ''A steady quantity'' ===
At the starting point we need a steady quantity. Where to get it from? As usual in this world, we need energy to create a quantity. We can get this energy from some power source. So, the first thing what we need (in this world) is a power source.
=== The problem: ''How to make it oscillate?'' ===
Then, we ask yourself, "How do we make the steady quantity oscillate?" But what does mean "to oscillate"? Simply speaking, to oscillate means just to make the quantity increase and decrease consecutively and regularly. How do we do this magic?
=== Preparing a steady quantity to be changed ===
It seems it's too difficult to make the very power source oscillate (power sources keep up constant their output quantities). Then, what do we do? We can act like in many situations of routine: instead to change the whole source energy we get some amount of energy from the source and store it in some "place" with the purpose to change it. As there are two kinds of energy - kinetic and potential, we can store energy in two kinds of energy accumulators (integrators). Let's do it; we have got the initial steady quantity. Examples: if we have stored a kinetic energy in an inductor, we obtain a constant current; if we have stored a potential energy in a capacitor, we obtain a constant voltage.
=== Changing the accumulated quantity ===
Now, we can begin doing the "veritable work" - to increase and decrase the steady quantity, in order to make it oscillate. How can we make it increase? Of course, by adding continuosly energy to the accumulator. And how can we make it decrease? Contrary, by subtracting continuosly energy from the accumulator. In both the cases we move, transport, transfer energy from one place to other - from the source to the accumulator and v.v.
==== Relaxation oscillations ====
''(...We might explain what an LC oscillation is, if we say what it is not. Here, we might say that an LC oscillation is not a '''relaxation''' one. Only, we would explain what a "relaxation oscillation" is. This phenomenon is no less vague and mystic than the LC phenomenon (I have never met good resources about it). Now, we have opportunity to reveal the secret behind relaxation phenomenon by comparing it with LC one. After that, we may move these thoughts to the future [[Circuit Idea/How to Make the Voltage across a Capacitor Wiggle|story]] about relaxation oscillations...)''
[[Image:Relaxation_oscillator_1000.jpg|right|thumb|550px|<center> A relaxation oscillator has only one accumulating element; the energy moves only in one direction.</center>]]
'''The basic idea.''' According to the powerful idea [[#Changing the accumulated quantity|above]], we might first build the simpler and more intuitive ''relaxation oscillator'' by using three elements: a flow (current) source, an accumulator of potential energy (a capacitor) and a load (a resistor). Such an arrangement operates in two stages as follows: in the first stage, we connect the current source to the accumulator and begin charging it; in the second stage, we connect the accumulator to the load (turn on the switch SW) and discharge it. Let's repeat it in other words: in a period of a relaxation oscillation, we first draw a kind of energy (usually, potential) from the flow source to fill the accumulator, then "suck dry" the energy from the accumulator and just "throw out" it to the environment. Thus, in the first stage of every period the source has to restore the energy in the accumulator.
'''Features.''' Note that the relaxation arrangement needs only one accumulator. It lies on the way of energy and serves as a buffer that interrupts temporarily the flow (only, the average flow remains constant). In this way, it intermits, tears to "pieces" the energy flow. It is interesting fact that a continuous current enters the accumulator while an intermittent current leaves it; so, we might say that a relaxation oscillator "discretisizes", "portens", "doses" the unceasing input flow of energy. At the same time, the accumulator's contents increases and decreases periodically. The shape of the curve is not sinusoidal because at the points of switching (at the peaks) the "flow-creating" quantity has a maximum magnitude. Note also that increase and decrease can have different durations. Examples of this possibility (see the analogies below) are a photoflash (slow charging, fast discharging), a toilet tank, a husband that fills slowly and continuously a family money deposit while his wife empties rapidly and regularly it:)
'''What does "relaxation oscillation" mean?''' I have been asking myself many times what the word "relaxation" means in this context. What does "relax" here? Maybe, the capacitor? If yes, when does the capacitor relax? Maybe, when we charge it (in this case, "relaxation" would mean restoring, retrieving, recreating the content of the accumulating element). Or maybe, the capacitor relaxes (returns to its initial "zero energy" state of equilibrium) when we discharge it...
'''Relaxation analogies.''' We can see many manifestations of this phenomenon in nature, routine, engineering and finally, in electronics. For example, I have a remembrance from my childhood how sometimes faulty toilet tanks began working intermittently (filling -> emptying -> filling -> emptying... up to infinity:) Similarly, imagine you were foolish enough to make a common money deposit with your wife:) Then, you begin working hard to feed up continuously the deposit. As a result, the amount of money increases continuously through time. Only, at some point your wife decides that's enough and draw out all the money accumulated. You begin working again... and she empties the deposit again... and this repeats again... and again... and again...:) [[User:Circuit-fantasist|Circuit-fantasist]] ([[User talk:Circuit-fantasist|talk]]) 20:06, 18 January 2008 (UTC)
==== LC oscillations ====
[[Image:LC_oscillator_1000.jpg|right|thumb|550px|<center>An LC oscillator has two accumulating elements; the energy circulates between them.</center>]]
'''The basic idea.''' Contrary, in order to create an ideal LC oscillation (assume an LC tank without losses), we charge the accumulator only once in the beginning (by turning on the switch SW on the bottom of the figure). Then, we "suck dry" the energy from the accumulator but do not "throw it away"; instead, we convert it into an opposite kind (''kinetic to potential'' or ''potential to kinetic'') and store the converted energy in another accumulator. We move, transfer, convey the energy from the one accumulator to the other. After, we use this energy to restore the energy of the first accumulator instead to "suck" energy from the source (we move back the energy). By the way, maybe is more correctly to say "energy moves" rather than "we move the energy". But why the energy moves by itself? What make it move? What make it move to and fro without end? Don't you think there is something mystic in this endless "ping-pong" movement?
'''Implementation.''' For this purpose, the LC arrangement consists of two heterogenious (regarding to the two kinds of energy) accumulating elements. Each of them can either provide energy (when it serves as a source) or store the energy (when it serves as a load). When act as a source, it is a weakening, depleting, exhausting source because the other (accumulating) element "sucks out" the source's energy. The energy moves from the source to the accumulator and the source's output quantity decreases.
==== Relaxation versus LC oscillations ====
===== Similarities =====
#Both the oscillating circuits contain at least one accumulating element that acts either as a source or as an integrator.
===== Differences =====
#An relaxation oscillator consists of only one accumulating element while an LC oscillator consists of two accumulating elements. #The relaxation accumulator is ''flow'' or ''pressure'' like; the LC accumulators are heterogenious (the one is ''flow-like'' and the other is ''pressure-like''). #An relaxation oscillator stores only one kind of energy (usually potential) in the accumulator while an LC oscillator stores two opposite kinds of energy (''kinetic'' and ''potential'') in the two accumulators. #In an relaxation oscillator we "throw away" the energy while in an LC oscillator we treasure it temporarily in an additional accumulator with the purpose of future usage. That's why, LC oscillators are more economical than relaxation ones. #Resonance phenomenon does not exist in relaxation circuit; it can be observed only in LC tank. #In an relaxation oscillator the energy moves only in one direction (source -> accumulator -> load) while in an LC oscillator the energy changes periodically its direction (it circulates between the two elements). #The shape of a relaxation oscillation is peaked, angular while the shape of an LC oscillation is rounded (sinusoidal). The reason of that is that at the peaks the source of a relaxation oscillator changes its output quantity with the maximum magnitude while the "source" of an LC oscillator (charged accumulator) does not change its output quantity. #The shape of the relaxation oscillation can be asymmetrical (the increase and the decrease can have different durations) while the shape of the LC oscillation is precisely symmetrical.
[[User:Circuit-fantasist|Circuit-fantasist]] ([[User talk:Circuit-fantasist|talk]]) 18:31, 24 January 2008 (UTC)

== Welcome message ==
Hello, and '''[[Wikibooks:Welcome, newcomers|welcome]]''' to [[Wikibooks]]!
Here are some tips to [[Help|help]] you get started: * To learn the wiki-markup-language syntax, see [[Help:Editing]]. * Make sure to sign your posts and comments with four tildes, like this: ~~~~ **There is a box at the top of the edit window (if javascript is enabled on your browser) that will insert it too (looks like part of a signature). This will let others know who left it, and make it easy to reply back to you. * Remember to conduct any editing experiments in the [[Wikibooks:Sandbox|sandbox]]. * You can tell the community something about yourself in your userpage. ** You can get to this page by clicking the tab at the top of the page labeled with your registered username. * Wikibooks is a collection of open-source textbooks. ([[WB:WIW|What is Wikibooks]]). * If you are a '''Wikipedian''', see [[Wikibooks:Wikibooks for Wikipedians]] for a primer on how things work here (it's a little different). ** If you want to base your work here on materials from Wikipedia, please use [[WB:RFI]] (requests for importation) to bring the material over in compliance with the GFDL. * If you're an '''instructor''' and plan on using Wikibooks for a class project, see [[Wikibooks:Guidelines for class projects]] * Please say hello at the [[Wikibooks:Reading room|Reading Room]] with any questions or ideas. * Eventually, you might want to read the [[Wikibooks:Manual of Style|Manual of Style]] and [[Wikibooks:Policies and guidelines|Policies and Guidelines]]. ** Help us by participating in policy and guideline creation. ** Please take a look at [[Wikibooks:Naming policy]] before starting a new book. * Remember to maintain a [[Wikibooks:Neutral point of view|Neutral point of view]]. * Explore, [[Wikibooks:Be bold in updating pages|be bold in editing pages]], and have fun!
You will find more resources in [[Wikibooks:Community Portal|Community Portal]]. If you want to ask a question, visit the [[Wikibooks:Study help desk|Study help desk]], the [[Wikibooks:Reading room|Reading Room]], [[Wikibooks:IRC channels|IRC channel]] or [[User_talk:Panic2k4|ask me personally on my talk page]]. For site news, see the [[WB:BB|Bulletin board]]. It might be a good idea to add that page to your "[[Special:Watchlist|watchlist]]" so that you can see when any new information is posted there. You can do that by clicking the tab labeled "watch" at the top of the page.
Good luck! --[[User:Panic2k4|Panic]] ([[User talk:Panic2k4|talk]]) 19:02, 24 January 2008 (UTC)

== Join Us! == {{#ifeq:"{{NAMESPACE}}"|"User talk"| Hello and '''[[Wikibooks:Welcome, newcomers|welcome]]''' to [[Wikibooks]], a collection of open-content textbooks! You should really consider [[Special:Userlogin|creating an account or logging in]]. Here are some advantages: * The use of a username of your choice. * Greater security and privacy, your IP address will be hidden from most users. * You get your own personal user page and talk page, instead of having to share it. * [[Special:Contributions/{{PAGENAME}}|Your contributions]] will be recognized as your own, and not confused with anyone elses. * The use of your own watchlist which shows when pages you are interested in have changed. * Your opinions carry greater weight in the [[Wikibooks:Decision making|decision making process]]. * You become a recognized member of the Wikibooks community. * Creating an account is easy and only takes a few minutes of your time. We hope that you choose to become a Wikibookian and [[Special:Userlogin|create an account]].
Feel free to ask any questions on my talk page or in the [[Wikibooks:Reading room|Reading room]].
Be sure to sign your posts and comments on talk pages with four tildes (~~~~), this will let other editors know you said it.

revision.text: I have made some significant edits to the numbers in the "How many people speak this language" section. I took my data from the Ethnologue (http://www.ethnologue.com/show_language.asp?code=ben). The ethnologue also says that the language's primary name is Bengali and not Bangla. I think that it might be appropriate to change this as well unless there's some compelling reason to leave it the way that it is.[[User:Rmawhorter|Rmawhorter]] ([[User talk:Rmawhorter|talk]]) 00:38, 25 January 2008 (UTC)

page.title: Robotics Kinematics and Dynamics/Serial Manipulator Position Kinematics

revision.text:
==Forward Position Kinematics==
The forward position kinematics problem can be stated as follows: given the different joint angles, what is the the position of the end-effector? With the previous sections in mind, the answer is rather simple: construct the different transformation matrices and combine them in the right way, the result being <math>^{ee}_{bs}T \,</math>, where <math>\{bs\}</math> is the base frame of the robot manipulator.
===Solution=== Suppose the mutual orientation matrices between adjacent links are known. (As the fixed parameters of each link are known, and the joint angles are a given to the problem, these can be calculated. One possible way to do this would be to make use of the Denavit-Hartenberg convention.) The transformation that relates the last and first frames in a serial manipulator arm, and thus, the solution to the forward kinematics problem, is then represented by the compound homogeneous transformation matrix. The axes are moving, thus, the compound homogeneous transformation matrix is found by premultiplying the individual transformation matrices: :<math>^{ee}_{bs}T = \, ^{N}_{0}T = \, ^{1}_{0}T \, ^{2}_{1}T \ldots \, ^{N-1}_{N-2}T \,^{N}_{N-1}T</math>
===Examples===
====The Planar Three-Link Manipulator==== [[Image:Planar-three-link-manipulator.svg|frame|right|A planar three link manipulator. Each <math>X_i</math>-axis lies along the <math>i</math>th link. Each <math>Y_i</math>-axis lies perpendicular to the corresponding <math>X_i</math>-axis in such a way that a positive <math>\theta_i</math> corresponds with a rotation from <math>X_i</math> to <math>Y_i</math>.]]
The equations below use 3 × 3 pose matrices, as this is just a 2-dimensional case (cf. the figure on the right).
The pose of the first link, relative to the reference frame, is given by (recall the elementary rotation about the z-axis from the previous section): :<math> T_1(\theta_1) = \begin{pmatrix} \cos(\theta_1) & -\sin(\theta_1) & 0 \\ \sin(\theta_1) & \cos(\theta_1) & 0 \\ 0 & 0 & 1 \end{pmatrix} </math>
The pose of the second link, relative to the first link, is given by: :<math> T_2(\theta_2) = \begin{pmatrix} \cos(\theta_2) & -\sin(\theta_2) & l_1 \\ \sin(\theta_2) & \cos(\theta_2) & 0 \\ 0 & 0 & 1 \end{pmatrix} </math>
This corresponds to a rotation by an angle <math>\theta_2</math> and a translation by a distance <math>l_1</math>, where <math>l_1</math> is the length of the first link.
The pose of the third link, relative to the second link, is given by: :<math> T_3(\theta_3) = \begin{pmatrix} \cos(\theta_3) & -\sin(\theta_3) & l_2 \\ \sin(\theta_3) & \cos(\theta_3) & 0 \\ 0 & 0 & 1 \end{pmatrix} </math>
The pose of the end effector, relative to the third link, is given by: :<math> T_4 = \begin{pmatrix} 1 & 0 & l_3 \\ 0 & 1 & 0 \\ 0 & 0 & 1 \end{pmatrix} </math>
The solution to the forward kinematics problem is then: :<math>^{ee}_{bs}T = \, ^4_0T(\theta_1, \theta_2, \theta_3) = \begin{pmatrix} c_{123} & -s_{123} & l_1 c_1 + l_2 c_{12} + l_3 c_{123} \\ s_{123} & c_{123} & l_1 s_1 + l_2 s_{12} + l_3 s_{123} \\ 0 & 0 & 1 \end{pmatrix} </math>
Hence: :<math> \begin{pmatrix} x \\ y \\ 1 \end{pmatrix} = T \begin{pmatrix} 0 \\ 0 \\ 1 \end{pmatrix} </math>
The resulting '''kinematic equations''' are: :<math> \begin{array}{l} x = l_1 \cos \theta_1 + l_2 \cos(\theta_1 + \theta_2) + l_3 \cos(\theta_1 + \theta_2 + \theta_3) \\ y = l_1 \sin \theta_1 + l_2 \sin(\theta_1 + \theta_2) + l_3 \sin(\theta_1 + \theta_2 + \theta_3) \end{array} </math>
==Inverse Position Kinematics==
The inverse kinematics problem is the opposite of the forward kinematics problem and can be summarized as follows: given the desired position of the end effector, what combinations of the joint angles can be used to achieve this position?
[[Image:Inverse-kinematics-multiple-solutions.svg|frame|right|An example of two different solutions for the inverse kinematics problem leading to the same end-effector position and orientation.]]
Two types of solutions can be considered: a closed-form solution and a numerical solution. Closed-form or analytical solutions are sets of equations that fully describe the connection between the end-effector position and the joint angles. Numerical solutions are found through the use of numerical algorithms, and can exist even when no closed-form solution is available. There may also be multiple solutions, or no solution at all.
===Example: Planar Three-Link Manipulator=== The inverse kinematics problem for this 2D manipulator can quite easily be solved algebraically.
From the earlier results (for simplicity, the displacement over the distance <math>l_3</math> shall be omitted here): :<math> ^3_0 T = \begin{pmatrix} c_{123} & -s_{123} & 0 & l_1 c_1 + l_2 c_{12} \\ s_{123} & c_{123} & 0 & l_1 s_1 + l_2 s_{12} \\ 0 & 0 & 1 & 0\\ 0 & 0 & 0 & 1 \\ \end{pmatrix} </math>
Now assume a given end-effector orientation in the following form: :<math> ^{ee}_{bs} T = \begin{pmatrix} c_{\phi} & -s_{\phi} & 0 & x \\ s_{\phi} & c_{\phi} & 0 & y \\ 0 & 0 & 1 & 0\\ 0 & 0 & 0 & 1 \\ \end{pmatrix} </math>
Equating the two previous expressions results in: :<math> \begin{array}{lll} c_{\phi} & = & c_{123} \\ s_{\phi} & = & s_{123} \\ x & = & l_1 c_1 + l_2 c_{12} \\ y & = & l_1 s_1 + l_2 s_{12} \\ \end{array} </math>
As: :<math> \begin{array}{lll} c_{12} & = & c_1c_2 - s_1 s_2 \\ s_{12} & = & c_1 s_2 + s_1 c_2 \\ \end{array} </math>, squaring both the expressions for <math>x</math> and <math>y</math> and adding them, leads to: :<math> x^2 + y^2 = l_1^2 + l_2^2 + 2 l_1 l_2 c_2 </math>
Solving for <math>c_2</math> leads to: :<math> c_2 = \frac{x^2 + y^2 - l_1^2 - l_2^2}{2 l_1 l_2} </math>, while <math>s_2</math> equals: :<math> s_2 = \pm \sqrt{1 - c_2^2} </math>, and, finally, <math>\theta_2</math>: :<math> \theta_2 = \mbox{Atan2}(s_2, c_2) </math>
'''Note''': The choice of the sign for <math>s_2</math> corresponds with one of the two solutions in the figure above.
The expressions for <math>x</math> and <math>y</math> may now be solved for <math>\theta_1</math>. In order to do so, write them like this: :<math> \begin{array}{lll} x & = & k_1 c_1 - k_2 s_1 \\ y & = & k_1 s_1 + k_2 c_1 \\ \end{array} </math> where <math>k_1 = l_1 + l_2 c_2</math>, and <math>k_2 = l_2 s_2</math>.
Let: :<math> \begin{array}{lll} r & = & \sqrt{k_1^2 + k_2^2} \\ \gamma & = & \mbox{Atan2}(k2,k1) \\ \end{array} </math>
Then: :<math> \begin{array}{lll} k_1 & = & r \cos \gamma \\ k_2 & = & r \sin \gamma \\ \end{array} </math>
Applying these to the above equations for <math>x</math> and <math>y</math>: :<math> \begin{array}{lll} x/r & = & \cos \gamma \, c_1 + \sin \gamma \, s_1 \\ y/r & = & \cos \gamma \, s_1 + \sin \gamma \, c_1 \\ \end{array} </math>, or: :<math> \begin{array}{lll} \cos (\gamma + \theta_1) & = & \frac{x}{r} \\ \sin (\gamma + \theta_1) & = & \frac{y}{r} \\ \end{array} </math>
Thus: :<math> \gamma + \theta_1 = \mbox{Atan2}(y,x) </math>
Hence: :<math> \theta_1 = \mbox{Atan2}(y,x) - \mbox{Atan2}(k_2,k_1) </math>
'''Note''': If <math>x = y = 0</math>, <math>\theta_1</math> actually becomes arbitrary.
<math>\theta_3</math> may now be solved from the first two equations for <math>s_{\phi}</math> and <math>c_{\phi}</math>: :<math> \theta_3 = \phi - \theta_1 - \theta_2 = \mbox{Atan2}(s_{\phi},c_{\phi}) - \theta_1 - \theta_2 </math>
{{BookCat}}

== Welcome! ==
{{{1|Welcome, {{PAGENAME}}!}}} {| style="background:white; border:1px solid #abd5f5;; padding:0px; border-spacing:0px; color: #000000;" ! style="background:#d0e5f5; color: #000000;" | [[Wikibooks:Welcome|Getting started]] with Wikibooks |- | style="padding:5px;" | * Wikibooks is a collection of open-source textbooks. Find out [[WB:WIW|what this means]]. * To sign your name (on talk pages), use four tildes, like this: ~~~~ * For help in using the wiki, see [[Using Wikibooks]]. * For information about the community here, see [[Wikibooks Community]]. * Explore, [[Wikibooks:Be bold|be bold]], and have fun! |}
Come introduce yourself at the [[WB:SLN|new users]] page. If you have any questions, you can ask there or contact me personally.--[[User:Laleena|Laleena]] ([[User talk:Laleena|talk]]) 00:26, 25 January 2008 (UTC)
== Wikijunior ==
I promise to start the work over there if you tell me what you think is worth expanding, etc. Thoughts? [[User:Laleena|Laleena]] ([[User talk:Laleena|talk]]) 01:15, 28 January 2008 (UTC) :Actually, I would like to do some work on [[Wikijunior:The Elements|The Elements]], but my main focus will probably be either [[Wikijunior:Languages|Languages]] or [[Wikijunior:Europe|Europe]]. That said, I am open to comments if you think other books need some help. Thoughts? [[User:Laleena|Laleena]] ([[User talk:Laleena|talk]]) 13:21, 29 January 2008 (UTC) ::I wasn't sure whether to edit here or on your talk page. Not sure what common protocol would be for that. The only books that seem to be done are Big Cats, Kings and Queens, The Solar System, World at Work and Alphabet. On the non-canonical list of books I'm thinking of indicating completion status so people know where each book is at. I'm planning on working on Languages for awhile but The Elements seems like a fine place to move to after that. I see value in working on almost any of the books there. The only two that I that I think I would struggle with would be The US Constitution (I'm Canadian) and WWII. [[User:Rmawhorter|Rmawhorter]] ([[User talk:Rmawhorter|talk]]) 15:30, 29 January 2008 (UTC) :::There is no protocol for responses, unfortunately :(. Anyhow, though, you might be able to nominate the above books, if not already FB, to Featured status. I know that the Solar System is FB, although I would also note that Languages is FB. I agree, though, that Languages is probably not good, I'll work there for a while. Thoughts? [[User:Laleena|Laleena]] ([[User talk:Laleena|talk]]) 00:12, 30 January 2008 (UTC) ::::I upgraded Arabic to publishable status because at the time I thought it quite comprehensive. If you wanted to make that point, though, you might write that in. Thoughts? [[User:Laleena|Laleena]] ([[User talk:Laleena|talk]]) 01:39, 31 January 2008 (UTC) :::::Could be your loss is that we don't have enough resources to catch up on this count. I suggest asking [[User:Mike.lifeguard|Mike.lifeguard]] or [[User:Whiteknight|Whiteknight]] for some input on the topic or Wikijunior in general. I suggest, however, checking out [[User:Theresa Knott|this user]], largely inactive now, but was a great contributor to Wikijunior. Thoughts? [[User:Laleena|Laleena]] ([[User talk:Laleena|talk]]) 01:56, 31 January 2008 (UTC)
*[[User:Laleena|Laleena]] ([[User talk:Laleena|talk]])

== Welcome message ==
Hello, and '''[[Wikibooks:Welcome, newcomers|welcome]]''' to [[Wikibooks]]!
Here are some tips to [[Help|help]] you get started: * To learn the wiki-markup-language syntax, see [[Help:Editing]]. * Make sure to sign your posts and comments with four tildes, like this: ~~~~ **There is a box at the top of the edit window (if javascript is enabled on your browser) that will insert it too (looks like part of a signature). This will let others know who left it, and make it easy to reply back to you. * Remember to conduct any editing experiments in the [[Wikibooks:Sandbox|sandbox]]. * You can tell the community something about yourself in your userpage. ** You can get to this page by clicking the tab at the top of the page labeled with your registered username. * Wikibooks is a collection of open-source textbooks. ([[WB:WIW|What is Wikibooks]]). * If you are a '''Wikipedian''', see [[Wikibooks:Wikibooks for Wikipedians]] for a primer on how things work here (it's a little different). ** If you want to base your work here on materials from Wikipedia, please use [[WB:RFI]] (requests for importation) to bring the material over in compliance with the GFDL. * If you're an '''instructor''' and plan on using Wikibooks for a class project, see [[Wikibooks:Guidelines for class projects]] * Please say hello at the [[Wikibooks:Reading room|Reading Room]] with any questions or ideas. * Eventually, you might want to read the [[Wikibooks:Manual of Style|Manual of Style]] and [[Wikibooks:Policies and guidelines|Policies and Guidelines]]. ** Help us by participating in policy and guideline creation. ** Please take a look at [[Wikibooks:Naming policy]] before starting a new book. * Remember to maintain a [[Wikibooks:Neutral point of view|Neutral point of view]]. * Explore, [[Wikibooks:Be bold in updating pages|be bold in editing pages]], and have fun!
You will find more resources in [[Wikibooks:Community Portal|Community Portal]]. If you want to ask a question, visit the [[Wikibooks:Study help desk|Study help desk]], the [[Wikibooks:Reading room|Reading Room]], [[Wikibooks:IRC channels|IRC channel]] or [[User_talk:Panic2k4|ask me personally on my talk page]]. For site news, see the [[WB:BB|Bulletin board]]. It might be a good idea to add that page to your "[[Special:Watchlist|watchlist]]" so that you can see when any new information is posted there. You can do that by clicking the tab labeled "watch" at the top of the page.
Good luck! --[[User:Panic2k4|Panic]] ([[User talk:Panic2k4|talk]]) 01:39, 25 January 2008 (UTC)

revision.comment: New page: == ImmortalBeauty == I'am ImmortalBeauty, I'am feamle and live in enternal darkness. I shan't give out any of my personal information, such as a/s/l or whatever the internet talk is. I s...
revision.text:
== ImmortalBeauty ==
I'am ImmortalBeauty, I'am feamle and live in enternal darkness. I shan't give out any of my personal information, such as a/s/l or whatever the internet talk is. I shall say that most of my postings on Wiki will be about Anti-slaughtering of Horses, Wolves or other wild animlas, or my faveorite topic, the immortal. I'am dark and twisted, which is why many tend to avoid me. I hate large crowds and would prefer to be alone in the dark. I prefer night to day, for day is when the sun comes out, and I'am much too pale for sunlight. I love to look at the moon, mainly when its full, with stars lingering around it like diamonds on black silk. I think that is the most romantic time of the wakeing hours. I like soft music, such as violin or piano, but I can also mosh to bands such as Slipknot or HIM. I'am a cutter I'll just throw that out there now, and if you have a problem with it you can go die.

== Join Us! == {{#ifeq:"{{NAMESPACE}}"|"User talk"| Hello and '''[[Wikibooks:Welcome, newcomers|welcome]]''' to [[Wikibooks]], a collection of open-content textbooks! You should really consider [[Special:Userlogin|creating an account or logging in]]. Here are some advantages: * The use of a username of your choice. * Greater security and privacy, your IP address will be hidden from most users. * You get your own personal user page and talk page, instead of having to share it. * [[Special:Contributions/{{PAGENAME}}|Your contributions]] will be recognized as your own, and not confused with anyone elses. * The use of your own watchlist which shows when pages you are interested in have changed. * Your opinions carry greater weight in the [[Wikibooks:Decision making|decision making process]]. * You become a recognized member of the Wikibooks community. * Creating an account is easy and only takes a few minutes of your time. We hope that you choose to become a Wikibookian and [[Special:Userlogin|create an account]].
Feel free to ask any questions on my talk page or in the [[Wikibooks:Reading room|Reading room]].
Be sure to sign your posts and comments on talk pages with four tildes (~~~~), this will let other editors know you said it.
|
'''This template must only be used on User talk pages.'''
}}-- '''– [[User:Mike.lifeguard|Mike.lifeguard]]''' | [[User talk:Mike.lifeguard|talk]] 03:24, 25 January 2008 (UTC)

== Welcome! == {{{1|Welcome, {{PAGENAME}}!}}} {| style="background:white; border:1px solid #abd5f5;; padding:0px; border-spacing:0px; color: #000000;" ! style="background:#d0e5f5; color: #000000;" | [[Wikibooks:Welcome|Getting started]] with Wikibooks |- | style="padding:5px;" | * Wikibooks is a collection of open-source textbooks. Find out [[WB:WIW|what this means]]. * To sign your name (on talk pages), use four tildes, like this: ~~~~ * For help in using the wiki, see [[Using Wikibooks]]. * For information about the community here, see [[Wikibooks Community]]. * Explore, [[Wikibooks:Be bold|be bold]], and have fun! |} Come introduce yourself at the [[WB:SLN|new users]] page. If you have any questions, you can ask there or contact me personally.-- '''– [[User:Mike.lifeguard|Mike.lifeguard]]''' | [[User talk:Mike.lifeguard|talk]] 06:28, 25 January 2008 (UTC) {{mbox|type=warning|msg='''Wikibooks regretfully cannot accept [[Wikibooks:Copyrights|copyrighted]] materials.'''
We [[Wikibooks:Welcome, newcomers|welcome]] and appreciate your contributions. If [[:Image:14524Vampire1.jpg]] uses an acceptable copyleft license or the copyright holders are willing to give [[Wikibooks:Boilerplate_request_for_permission|permission]] to use it under an acceptable copyleft license, then we need you to include the licensing information with it. Please read [[Wikibooks:Media]] to learn more about our requirements. After 7 days if this is not addressed appropriately we will have to delete it [[WB:COPYVIO|per policy]]. If you have any questions you can ask me personally or ask in the [[WB:HELP|reading room]]. Thank you; Happy editing!  '''– [[User:Mike.lifeguard|Mike.lifeguard]]''' | [[User talk:Mike.lifeguard|talk]] 19:07, 26 January 2008 (UTC)}} :Also, please note that claiming an upload is your work when it isn't is grounds for a block. If you do it again, I will do so. Please provide correct and complete license information on your uploads only. Anything less will get you blocked and/or your uploads deleted. This all per policy; if you have questions, please ask on my talk page.  '''– [[User:Mike.lifeguard|Mike.lifeguard]]''' | [[User talk:Mike.lifeguard|talk]] 22:36, 26 January 2008 (UTC)

== You have been warned == {{mbox|type=serious|msg='''Please do not make inappropriate edits to Wikibooks.'''
Edits that you have made have been considered inappropriate or even disruptive by your fellow contributors. Please use the [[Wikibooks:Sandbox|sandbox]] in the future if you wish to test something out. For a description of the type of content that we do allow, see [[WB:WIW]]. If you have questions about this, or need help, ask at the [[WB:HELP|Reading Room Assistance]] page. [[User:Herbythyme|Herby]] [[User talk:Herbythyme|talk thyme]] 08:41, 25 January 2008 (UTC)}}

{{Latin/Spoken}} '''Chapter One, Lesson Two - Telling people where you're from and what language you speak:''' In this chapter you'll study basic conversations.
==Lesson 2== ===Countries, inhabitants and the language=== {| border="1" |- | '''Country''' || '''People''' || '''Adjective''' || '''Language''' |- | ''Roma'' ("Rome") || ''Romanus'' ("a Roman") || ''Romanus'', ''Romana'', ''Romanum'' ("Roman") || ''Lingua Latina'' ("Latin") |- | ''Anglia'' ("England") || ''Anglus'' ("a Englishman") || ''Anglicus'', ''Anglica'', ''Anglicum'' ("English") || ''Lingua Anglica'' ("English") |- | ''Islandia'' ("Iceland") || ''Islandus'' ("an Icelander") || ''Islandicus'', ''Islandica'', ''Islandicum'' ("Icelandic") || ''Lingua Islandica'' ("Icelandic") |- | ''Japonia'' ("Japan") || ''Japonus'' ("a Japanese") || ''Japonicus'', ''Japonica'', ''Japonicum'' ("Japanese") || ''Lingua Japonica'' ("Japanese") |}
====Nationality==== :''If you're referring to an English man you say ''Anglic'''us''''' and if you're referring to an English woman you say ''Anglic'''a'''''. The ending '''-us''' is used for men and the ending '''-a''' for women. If you're going to say "I'm Japanese" you just need to say ''Sum Japonic'''us'''.'' if you're male, and ''Sum Japonic'''a''''' if you're a female. Examples: * ''Sum Islandic'''a''''' = I'm Icelandic (female) * ''Sum Roman'''us''''' = I'm Roman (male) * ''Sum Japonic'''a''''' = I'm Japanese (female) * ''Sum Anglic'''us''''' = I'm English (male)
====Language==== To say that you "speak" a language you just need to say ''loquor''. ''Loquor'' means "I speak", so if you're going to say "I speak Latin", you say: ''Linguam latinam loquor''. Now don't get angry and confused over why "lingua latina" is now "lingua'''m''' latina'''m'''". It will be explained later. For now, just remember that you add an 'm' to a word when it's the object. Now, some examples: * ''Linguam Anglicam loquor.'' = I speak English * ''Linguam Latinam loquor.'' = I speak Latin. Now to make the sentence '''negative''' you simply add ''[[wikt:en:non#Latin|non]]'' which means "no" or "not": * ''Linguam Latinam '''non''' loquor'' = I '''don't''' speak Latin. * ''Linguam Islandicam '''non''' loquor'' = I '''don't''' speak Icelandic. * ''Linguam Japonicam '''non''' loquor'' = I '''don't''' speak Japanese.
====Referring to other people==== If you're going to say "you are English" or "you are Roman" we need how to say "you are". You almost never have to use [[w:en:personal pronouns|personal pronouns]] (I, we, they, you) in Latin because they are inferred from context or the verbs. So if you are going to say "you are" you simply say "es". Example: * ''Es Islandic'''us''''' = You are Icelandic (male) * ''Non es Japonic'''a''''' = You aren't Japanese (female) * ''Es Roman'''a''''' = You are Roman (female) * ''Es Anglic'''us''''' = You are English (male)
Now you rarely need to ''tell'' people of what nationality they are (what did you say? "you rarely need to use Latin either"? Just shut up and pay attention!). If you want to ask people a question, you add ''[[wikt:en:-ne|-ne]]'' to the first word of the sentence. For example: * ''Es Anglicus'' = You are English (male) *: ''Es'''ne''' Anglicus?'' = ''Are'' you English'''?''' (male) * ''Es Japonica'' = You are Japanese (girl) *: ''Es'''ne''' Japonica?'' = ''Are'' you Japanese'''?''' (girl) * ''Sum Islandicus'' = I'm Icelandic (male) *: ''Sum'''ne''' Islandicus'' = ''Am'' I Icelandic'''?''' (male)
===Dialogue=== {| class="wikitable" {{Latin/Table|Dialogue|Are you Japanese?|Esne Japonica?}} |- !Speakers||Latin||English |- !Maria |Salve Eva. |Hello Eva. |- !Eva |Salve Maria! |Hi Maria! |- !Maria |Eva, es'''ne''' Japonica? |Eva, are you Japanese? |- !Eva |Non. Non sum Japonica. |No. I'm not Japanese. |- !Maria |Es'''ne''' Romana? |Are you Roman? |- !Eva |Hehae, non. Non sum Romana. Sum Islandica. |Hehe, no. I'm not Roman, I'm Icelandic. |}
===Asking what languages=== Here we'll learn how to ask people what languages they speak. First let's overview a very limited conjugation of the verb "to speak". * ''loquor'' = I speak * ''loqueris'' = you speak * ''loquitur'' = he/she/it speaks Now it would be advisable for you to learn by heart, as it'll prove immensely useful. Let's now learn a few things. ==== Do you speak? ==== To learn how to ask what people know or speak you must first learn to "declare" that they know something. ''E.g.'': * ''Linguam Latinam loquor.'' = I speak Latin. * ''Linguam Anglicam loquitur.'' = He/she speaks English. * ''Linguam Islandicam non loquor.'' = I don't speak Icelandic. * ''Linguam Japonicam loqueris.'' = You speak Japanese. Now you wonder; "how can I ask questions?". Did you just learn the [[wikt:en:enclitic|enclitic]] (don't worry about knowing that word, you're never going to use it) '''-ne''' which makes sentences into questions? You just add it to the first word of the sentence! * ''Loqueris'''ne'''?'' = Do you speak? * ''Linguam'''ne''' Latinam loqueris?'' = Do you speak Latin? * ''Linguam'''ne''' Latinam loquitur?'' = Does he/she speak Latin?
How would we say "don't you speak Latin"? Did you maybe think since we know how to say "do you speak Latin" and we know how say "no" (''non'') that it's: * <s>Linguamne Latinam non loqueris?</s> ... Nope sorry that's wrong. The way to say "don't" or "aren't" is the word '''''[[wikt:en:nonne|nonne]]'''''! (you might also see that it's made from ''non'' and ''-ne'') * '''''Nonne''' Linguam Latinam loqueris?'' = '''Don't''' you speak Latin? * '''''Nonne''' Anglicus es?'' = '''Aren't''' you English? (referring to a man) * '''''Nonne''' Lingua Latina est?'' = '''Isn't''' this Latin? *: <small>Notice that the word Latin is written as "Lingua Latina" but not as "Linguam Latinam". This is because nothing "affects" it.</small>
===Dialogue=== Now let's look at some dialogue (in a freak turn of events the speakers are Caesar and Brutus)..
{| class="wikitable" {{Latin/Table|Dialogue|Are you Japanese?|Esne Japonica?}} |- !Speakers||Latin||English |- !Caesar |Ave<ref>''Ave'' was a very formal expression of greetings. Were this an informal meeting of friends they would simply use ''salve''.</ref> Brute.<ref>The reason why Brutus' name is written as ''Brute'' is because he's addressing him. This will be explained later. (v. [[wikt:en:et tu, Brute|et tu, Brut'''e''']])</ref> |Hail Brutus! |- !Brutus |Ave Caesar. Quid agis hodie? |Hail Caesar. How are you today? |- !Caesar |Bene me habeo.<ref>Literally meaning "I have me well".</ref> |I am well. |- !Brutus |Caesar, nonne Romanus es? |Caesar, aren't you Roman? |- !Caesar |Sic est. Cur? |I am. Why? |- !Brutus |Nihil est. Linguamne Latinam loqueris? |It's nothing. Do you speak Latin? |- !Caesar |Sic est, Linguam Latinam loquor! Cur? |Yes, I speak Latin! Why? |- !Brutus |Cur non? Ei.. Nihil est. Vale. |Why not? Oh.. It's nothing. Good bye. |- !Caesar |..Vale.. |..bye.. |}
==References== <references/> A complete textbook for spoken Classical Latin can be found on Google Books: http://www.google.co.uk/books?id=GJgAAAAAYAAJ This textbook can be heard read out aloud here: http://latinum.mypodcast.com

{{WikiProject Languages}}

revision.comment: '''Plate tectonics''' is the theory (nothing in science can be absolutely proven) that the Earth is constantly moving, usually only a few inches per century. Plate tectonics mainly deals with the crus
revision.text:
THIS IS A TEST PAGE SOLELY FOR MY USE!!!! IF YOU WANT TO USE IT PLEASE ASK ME!!!!
'''Plate tectonics''' is the theory (nothing in science can be absolutely proven) that the Earth is constantly moving, usually only a few inches per century. Plate tectonics mainly deals with the crust of the earth, not the mantle or core. The theory of Pangaea is relative to this. The Pangaea theory in its standard form says that the continents as they are now have moved apart over millions of years to make the world the way it is today. Plate tectonics is what causes volcanoes and earthquakes. It can also help with ocean-floor building, etc. When these plates move apart too fast, an earthquake happens. Earthquakes can lead to volcanic eruptions.

Hello. Hopefully you have come here to start with the effort to clear our [[Category:NPOV Disputes|database of NPOV violations]]. Well, the steps to this are: #Read-perhaps the vios are catered to, say, a graduate scientist. Check. #Re-edit-if your reading shows the concentration of NPOV, then GO FOR IT!!!! It is important that you, however, replace the NPOV with very good information that can be verified. #Reform-even if you have cycled through reading, and perhaps re-editing, and are convinced that it is hopelessly NPOV, then [[Wikibooks:Votes for deletion|nominate it for deletion]]. If you add it to this [[/List of NPOV Violations/]], however, you can be saved the trouble of nominating it, because periodically I will post the contents of it up for deletion, and then there will be mass action.

revision.text:
== Volume == Volume is like area expanded out into 3 dimensions. Area deals with only 2 dimensions. For volume we have to consider another dimension. Area can be thought of as how much space some drawing takes up on a flat piece of paper. Volume can be thought of as how much space an object takes up. == Volume formulae == {| class=wikitable |- ! colspan = 3 | Common [[equation]]s for volume: |- !Shape !Equation !Variables |- |A [[Cube (geometry)|cube]]: |s^3 = s \cdot s \cdot s |''s'' = length of a side |- |A rectangular [[Prism (geometry)|prism]]: |l \cdot w \cdot h |l = ''l''ength, w = ''w''idth, h = ''h''eight |- |A [[cylinder (geometry)|cylinder]] (circular prism): |\pi r^2 \cdot h |''r'' = radius of circular face, ''h'' = height |- |Any prism that has a constant cross sectional area along the height: |A \cdot h |''A'' = area of the base, ''h'' = height |- |A [[sphere]]: |\frac{4}{3} \pi r^3 |''r'' = radius of sphere
which is the [[integral]] of the [[Surface Area]] of a [[sphere]] |- |An [[ellipsoid]]: |\frac{4}{3} \pi abc |''a'', ''b'', ''c'' = semi-axes of ellipsoid |- |A [[Pyramid (geometry)|pyramid]]: |\frac{1}{3}Ah |''A'' = area of the base, ''h'' = height of pyramid |- |A [[Cone (geometry)|cone]] (circular-based pyramid): |\frac{1}{3} \pi r^2 h |''r'' = radius of [[circle]] at base, ''h'' = distance from base to tip . |} (The units of volume depend on the units of length - if the lengths are in meters, the volume will be in cubic '''meters''', etc.) ==Pappus' Theorem== The volume of any solid whose cross sectional areas are all the same is equal to that cross sectional area times the distance the centroid(the center of gravity in a physical object) would travel through the solid. [[:Image:PappusCentroidTheoremExample.jpg]] ==Cavalieri's Principle== If two solids are contained between two parallel planes and every plane parallel to these two plane has equal cross sections through these two solids, then their volumes are equal. [[:Image:CavalierisPrinciple.jpg]] [[Category:Geometry (book)]]

== Welcome message ==
Hello, and '''[[Wikibooks:Welcome, newcomers|welcome]]''' to [[Wikibooks]]!
Here are some tips to [[Help|help]] you get started: * To learn the wiki-markup-language syntax, see [[Help:Editing]]. * Make sure to sign your posts and comments with four tildes, like this: ~~~~ **There is a box at the top of the edit window (if javascript is enabled on your browser) that will insert it too (looks like part of a signature). This will let others know who left it, and make it easy to reply back to you. * Remember to conduct any editing experiments in the [[Wikibooks:Sandbox|sandbox]]. * You can tell the community something about yourself in your userpage. ** You can get to this page by clicking the tab at the top of the page labeled with your registered username. * Wikibooks is a collection of open-source textbooks. ([[WB:WIW|What is Wikibooks]]). * If you are a '''Wikipedian''', see [[Wikibooks:Wikibooks for Wikipedians]] for a primer on how things work here (it's a little different). ** If you want to base your work here on materials from Wikipedia, please use [[WB:RFI]] (requests for importation) to bring the material over in compliance with the GFDL. * If you're an '''instructor''' and plan on using Wikibooks for a class project, see [[Wikibooks:Guidelines for class projects]] * Please say hello at the [[Wikibooks:Reading room|Reading Room]] with any questions or ideas. * Eventually, you might want to read the [[Wikibooks:Manual of Style|Manual of Style]] and [[Wikibooks:Policies and guidelines|Policies and Guidelines]]. ** Help us by participating in policy and guideline creation. ** Please take a look at [[Wikibooks:Naming policy]] before starting a new book. * Remember to maintain a [[Wikibooks:Neutral point of view|Neutral point of view]]. * Explore, [[Wikibooks:Be bold in updating pages|be bold in editing pages]], and have fun!
You will find more resources in [[Wikibooks:Community Portal|Community Portal]]. If you want to ask a question, visit the [[Wikibooks:Study help desk|Study help desk]], the [[Wikibooks:Reading room|Reading Room]], [[Wikibooks:IRC channels|IRC channel]] or [[User_talk:Panic2k4|ask me personally on my talk page]]. For site news, see the [[WB:BB|Bulletin board]]. It might be a good idea to add that page to your "[[Special:Watchlist|watchlist]]" so that you can see when any new information is posted there. You can do that by clicking the tab labeled "watch" at the top of the page.
Good luck! --[[User:Panic2k4|Panic]] ([[User talk:Panic2k4|talk]]) 01:19, 26 January 2008 (UTC)

== Key of a Trombone ==
The traditional straight tenor trombone is written in the key of C, also called "Concert Pitch." This means that trombone, unlike many wind instruments, will play in the same notes as a Piano.
Many trombones have an "F key" or "F attachment" which adds piping to the trombone allowing it to play in the key of F. This is often used to improve the tuning of the instrument as it gets farther down the scale, or to make faster passages less difficult to play.
Bass Trombones often have similar Keys in F or even Eb, sometimes these can be played at the same time to produce an even lower tone.
== Scales ==
The trombone can play in any scale, however generally the easiest and most common are the first few flatted keys. Bb, Eb, Ab, Db. These are the keys most commonly played in beginning trombone music.
Scales are often learned in terms of slide position, for example, 2 octaves of the Bb scale would be: 1 6 4 3 1 4 2 1 3 1 3 1 #2 2 1. Gradually, as the player progresses, this should be developed into knowing the notes of the scale as well to encourage the understanding of what they are playing, not just how.
You may notice the notation "#2" in the scale numbers above, this indicates a "short second," the slide is moved slightly closer to the mouthpiece (a process which takes a great deal of practice and good ear) to produce a more in tune note than the "normal" position for the note. Such "short" positions are generally only used in the very upper reaches of a trombone's range. Flat positions are more commonly used for trombonists in the valve or F-attachment range like an E below the staff being in b2 position.
{{BookCat}}

== Motivation == You want to generate a user interface form directly from a model.
== Method == Because XForms is a declarative XML file it can be generated by transforming a model of your data directly into a form. The most common way to store a model of hierarchical data is using an XML Schema. A server-side program will scan the XML Schema document and for each element found it will create the appropriate XForms elements.
Generated forms have the advantage over hand-crafted forms in that they can can be generated with the same set of transforms. If you change your form standards all the forms can be quickly be regenerated. Many of these advantage can be gained by pushing the formatting and layout functionality of a form into CSS style sheets. But there are also many aspects of a form that are not governed by a style sheet.
If you using a consistent naming convention in your forms you can also use this naming convention to decide what types of input controls to generate based on the information in the element name. For example simple names and amounts will map to '''input''' controls, boolean true/false values will map to inputs formatted as checkboxes, dates will use calendar selectors, text objects will use '''textarea''' controls and codes will use '''select''' or '''select1''' controls.
Here is a sample of how ISO Data element Representation Terms map to XForms controls:
{| border="1" cellspacing="0" cellpadding="5" align="left" ! Representation Term ! XForms Control |- | Amount, Name | input |- | Indicator | input with type="xs:boolean" |- | Date | input with type="xs:date" |- | Text | Textarea |}

We [[Wikibooks:Welcome, newcomers|welcome]] and appreciate your contributions. If [[:How to make Banana Crumb Muffins]] uses an acceptable copyleft license or the copyright holders are willing to give [[Wikibooks:Boilerplate_request_for_permission|permission]] to use it under an acceptable copyleft license, then we need you to include the licensing information with it. Please read [[Wikibooks:Media]] to learn more about our requirements. After 7 days if this is not addressed appropriately we will have to delete it [[WB:COPYVIO|per policy]]. If you have any questions you can ask me personally or ask in the [[WB:HELP|reading room]]. Thank you; Happy editing! {{{2|}}}}} [[User:Mattb112885|Mattb112885]] ([[User talk:Mattb112885|talk to me]]) 14:59, 26 January 2008 (UTC) == Off topic pages == Please stop creating pages that are not textbook material - thanks --[[User:Herbythyme|Herby]] [[User talk:Herbythyme|talk thyme]] 16:20, 26 January 2008 (UTC)

== Welcome message ==
Hello, and '''[[Wikibooks:Welcome, newcomers|welcome]]''' to [[Wikibooks]]!
Here are some tips to [[Help|help]] you get started: * To learn the wiki-markup-language syntax, see [[Help:Editing]]. * Make sure to sign your posts and comments with four tildes, like this: ~~~~ **There is a box at the top of the edit window (if javascript is enabled on your browser) that will insert it too (looks like part of a signature). This will let others know who left it, and make it easy to reply back to you. * Remember to conduct any editing experiments in the [[Wikibooks:Sandbox|sandbox]]. * You can tell the community something about yourself in your userpage. ** You can get to this page by clicking the tab at the top of the page labeled with your registered username. * Wikibooks is a collection of open-source textbooks. ([[WB:WIW|What is Wikibooks]]). * If you are a '''Wikipedian''', see [[Wikibooks:Wikibooks for Wikipedians]] for a primer on how things work here (it's a little different). ** If you want to base your work here on materials from Wikipedia, please use [[WB:RFI]] (requests for importation) to bring the material over in compliance with the GFDL. * If you're an '''instructor''' and plan on using Wikibooks for a class project, see [[Wikibooks:Guidelines for class projects]] * Please say hello at the [[Wikibooks:Reading room|Reading Room]] with any questions or ideas. * Eventually, you might want to read the [[Wikibooks:Manual of Style|Manual of Style]] and [[Wikibooks:Policies and guidelines|Policies and Guidelines]]. ** Help us by participating in policy and guideline creation. ** Please take a look at [[Wikibooks:Naming policy]] before starting a new book. * Remember to maintain a [[Wikibooks:Neutral point of view|Neutral point of view]]. * Explore, [[Wikibooks:Be bold in updating pages|be bold in editing pages]], and have fun!
You will find more resources in [[Wikibooks:Community Portal|Community Portal]]. If you want to ask a question, visit the [[Wikibooks:Study help desk|Study help desk]], the [[Wikibooks:Reading room|Reading Room]], [[Wikibooks:IRC channels|IRC channel]] or [[User_talk:Panic2k4|ask me personally on my talk page]]. For site news, see the [[WB:BB|Bulletin board]]. It might be a good idea to add that page to your "[[Special:Watchlist|watchlist]]" so that you can see when any new information is posted there. You can do that by clicking the tab labeled "watch" at the top of the page.
Good luck! --[[User:Panic2k4|Panic]] ([[User talk:Panic2k4|talk]]) 17:23, 26 January 2008 (UTC)

== Join Us! == {{#ifeq:"{{NAMESPACE}}"|"User talk"| Hello and '''[[Wikibooks:Welcome, newcomers|welcome]]''' to [[Wikibooks]], a collection of open-content textbooks! You should really consider [[Special:Userlogin|creating an account or logging in]]. Here are some advantages: * The use of a username of your choice. * Greater security and privacy, your IP address will be hidden from most users. * You get your own personal user page and talk page, instead of having to share it. * [[Special:Contributions/{{PAGENAME}}|Your contributions]] will be recognized as your own, and not confused with anyone elses. * The use of your own watchlist which shows when pages you are interested in have changed. * Your opinions carry greater weight in the [[Wikibooks:Decision making|decision making process]]. * You become a recognized member of the Wikibooks community. * Creating an account is easy and only takes a few minutes of your time. We hope that you choose to become a Wikibookian and [[Special:Userlogin|create an account]].
Feel free to ask any questions on my talk page or in the [[Wikibooks:Reading room|Reading room]].
Be sure to sign your posts and comments on talk pages with four tildes (~~~~), this will let other editors know you said it.
|
'''This template must only be used on User talk pages.'''
}}-- '''– [[User:Mike.lifeguard|Mike.lifeguard]]''' | [[User talk:Mike.lifeguard|talk]] 22:15, 26 January 2008 (UTC)

page.title: Wikibooks:Requests for deletion/Wikibooks:Language Learning Difficulty for English Speakers

revision.text:
== [[Wikibooks:Language Learning Difficulty for English Speakers|Language Learning Difficulty for English Speakers]] == {| cellspacing="5" cellpadding="5" style="border: 1px red solid; background: #ffffcc; width: 95%; margin: auto; color: #000000;" | style="width: 40px; text-align: center;" | [[Image:Stop hand nuvola.svg|30px]] | Closed as '''keep''' as there's no consensus here to delete. Additionally, conversion to a Subject: page as a basis for another method of organizing the language books is left open as a possibility, provided that this system is presented as that of the FSI and not as "gospel truth." Certainly objections to it's methodology and/or conclusions are possible. Both sides must be [[WB:OR|verifiable]] in whatever arguments are put forward - no opinions please. Interested parties may further discuss conversion to a Subject: page on [[Talk:Language Learning Difficulty for English Speakers]], though opinions expressed here are not to be overlooked.  '''– [[User:Mike.lifeguard|Mike.lifeguard]]''' | [[User talk:Mike.lifeguard|talk]] 13:45, 21 January 2008 (UTC) |- | colspan="2" style="border-top: 1px red dashed;" | This was tagged for [[WB:SPEEDY|speedy deletion]] by [[User:Girdi]], but I don't think it meets any of the speedy deletion criteria. His reason for deletion was "This is just plain nonsense." I have no opinion for now; I've asked Girdi to expand on his reasons for deletion. FYI, there seems to be a lengthy discussion on the talk page concerning this.  '''– [[User:Mike.lifeguard|Mike.lifeguard]]''' | [[User talk:Mike.lifeguard|talk]] 15:05, 21 December 2007 (UTC) {{Vote/Transwiki}} and {{del|speedy delete}} I've taken a brief look at it, and the arguments on the talk page. The reasons listed there seem to focus on whether or not its accurate and its general value. However what I haven't seen pointed out and I believe qualifies for its deletion is that [[WB:WIW#Wikibooks is not an encyclopedia|Wikibooks modules are not individual encyclopedia-formatted articles]]. This should be transwikied to [[w:|Wikipedia]] and/or [[v:|Wikiversity]] if such a list doesn't already exist on both wikis. In either case this should be deleted, as its not appropriate contents for Wikibooks. --[[User:Darklama|dark]][[User_talk:Darklama|lama]] 20:27, 21 December 2007 (UTC) :'''Move''' I think this is far better for Wikiversity then Wikipedia, but it is certainly not a book. However, this page does a lot to explain things like {{tlx|Category 3}} and [[:Category:Category 2 Languages]], which are prevalent in the foreign languages book. I recommend, in lieu of a transwiki, that this page be moved to [[:Category:Languages by category]] as an explanatory note for that system of organization. --'''Whiteknight''' ([[User:Whiteknight|Page]]) ([[User talk:Whiteknight|Talk]]) 13:28, 24 December 2007 (UTC) : That categories you have quoted appear to have been added during the development of the book/page which is up for deletion. If the book is deleted then I would hope that these silly categories are also removed as they have no international uses and are not recognized by major foreign-language learning publishers or the European Council of Europe for Languages. [[User:Xania|Xania]] [[Image:Flag_of_Italy.svg|15px]][[User talk:Xania|talk]] 19:28, 30 December 2007 (UTC) '''Keep''' I find it quite interesting and useful. [[User:Opiaterein|Opiaterein]] ([[User talk:Opiaterein|talk]]) 03:18, 25 December 2007 (UTC) :{{del}} I have long argued that this page is crap. I've never heard of such a dategory of languages before and don't agree with it's aims or how it guages the difficulty of languages. [[User:Xania|Xania]] [[Image:Flag_of_Italy.svg|15px]][[User talk:Xania|talk]] 20:13, 28 December 2007 (UTC) :{{del}} Nonsense. However, I would probably keep the content somewhere off Wikibooks, preferably elsewhere on the Wiki areas. [[User:Laleena|Laleena]] ([[User talk:Laleena|talk]]) 20:21, 28 December 2007 (UTC) :'''Move''' As per Whiteknight suggestion. I also share the opinion that the list if flawed or oversimplified, but as it is stands it only states the views of The Foreign Service Institute (FSI) of the US Department of State (be it right or wrong) as such it can serve as the basis for analysis or the creation of a better listing with similar objectives that would/could indeed be made useful. --[[User:Panic2k4|Panic]] ([[User talk:Panic2k4|talk]]) 20:29, 28 December 2007 (UTC) :{{del}} Indeed; it seems to be just a rough indicator of a language's difficulty. [[User:Mouse is back|Mouse]] [[User talk:Mouse is back|is]] [[Special:Contributions/Mouse is back|back]] 01:02, 1 January 2008 (UTC) :'''Proposal''' I would like to suggest the following changes to this page, as an alternative to deletion: :#Page be moved to [[Subject:FSI Language Difficulties]] or [[Subject:Languages by Difficulty]], or something similar. :#Manual book lists on this page be deleted, and replaced with DPL-based lists :#Text on this page be reworked to be shorter, do more to describe what the FSI is, what the category system means, how it is developed, etc. Also include a note that this might not be an "international standard" way of categorizing languages. :Considering that we have an entire Subject namespace for organizing things, I guess I don't see a reason not to employ this particular organizational method if there is any value to it. --'''Whiteknight''' ([[User:Whiteknight|Page]]) ([[User talk:Whiteknight|Talk]]) 20:43, 1 January 2008 (UTC) ::{{support}} --[[User:Panic2k4|Panic]] ([[User talk:Panic2k4|talk]]) 23:55, 8 January 2008 (UTC) ::[[Image:Symbol support vote.svg|15px]] '''Support WK's proposal''' - the language books need to be organized in various ways (currently it's only by language family); difficulty may well be a valid method (how useful a method it is has no bearing on this discussion). This is at least half-decent meta-content, which is perfectly suited to being moved to the Subject: namespace. Perhaps [[Subject:Languages]] should have tabs like [[Subject:Programming]] for various methods of sorting the books below the level of [[Subject:Languages]]. One tab for language families, another for difficulty, another for size of native speaking population, another for...? (as opposed to the simple subcategory method we're using now (which only works because we're only using one sub-categorization method - language family).  '''– [[User:Mike.lifeguard|Mike.lifeguard]]''' | [[User talk:Mike.lifeguard|talk]] 01:42, 11 January 2008 (UTC)
::{{support}} I also support Wk's proposal. It makes logical sense. - [[User:Anonymous Dissident|Anonymous Dissident]][[User_talk:Anonymous Dissident|Talk]] 15:25, 11 January 2008 (UTC) ::: I can't believe that some people are arguing for this to be kept. Yes we need categorization for our language books but this should be in terms of language families (romance, germanic, etc.) or geographical area (European, African). The term 'category 1/2/3' also gives the impression that we are referring to the importance of the language and not its difficulty. It's always difficult to determine how hard a language is but this list has no recognized basis, is not used in the field of language teaching and ignores the fact that the most important thing determining how difficult the language is is the student's own abilities. This page is quite simply rubbish. [[User:Xania|Xania]] [[Image:Flag_of_Italy.svg|15px]][[User talk:Xania|talk]] 22:26, 11 January 2008 (UTC) ::::In principle, language difficulty is as valid an organizational scheme as any other you've mentioned. The problem is with finding a rating system for difficulty that's valid. This one happens to be backed up by "The Foreign Service Institute (FSI) of the US Department of State." It may be BS, it may not be. I don't know, and I don't care. Since it's some (presumably) semi-reliable body that's put this together, I'm in no position to argue with them. Maybe leaving the categories as 1/2/3 isn't the best idea - rename them then. The Subject: page could certainly have some notice at the top that "the most important thing determining how difficult the language is is the student's own abilities. This page is quite simply rubbish" as long as it's [[WB:OR|not just your opinion]]. I might word it differently: "The FSI of the US State Department says this categorization scheme is a good one, but many experts in linguistics note that intrinsic ability and previous experience are the most important factors in language learning."  '''– [[User:Mike.lifeguard|Mike.lifeguard]]''' | [[User talk:Mike.lifeguard|talk]] 18:20, 16 January 2008 (UTC) :::::Voted retain to broaden discussion topic & nature. If required necessary move to another part of Wikipedia? :::::According to my understanding FSI is the origin, of many of the most common language proficiency scales currently used including it's USA successor: Interagency Language Roundtable (ILR) Scale. :::::Many other foreign language government authorities have created similar common language proficiency frameworks. Many of these follow the very same assumptions that FSI created years ago with some minor tweaks, for example. :::::"This model has had a strong influence on the design and development of other language frameworks in the academic community: the American Council for the Teaching of Foreign Languages (ACTFL) Proficiency Guidelines, the New Brunswick Oral Proficiency Scale and the International Second Language Proficiency Ratings (Australia). The Oral Proficiency Interview Scale used by Foreign Affairs Canada also mirrors the ILR scale. (Paragraph quoted taken from a Canadian Government webpage here. [http://www.canadianheritage.gc.ca/progs/lo-ol/pubs/new-nouvelles_perspectives/app-annB_e.cfm] :::::This same Canadian government source goes on to say this: "Discussion: The ILR framework (and, by virtue, the ACTFL framework and others modeled after it) did not emerge from any particular theory of language learning. As pointed out by Omaggio-Hadley (1993, p. 13), these frameworks “came about primarily as a result of the perceived needs of practitioners in both government and academic settings who wanted to make a difference in the way languages were taught and communicate more effectively about the results of that instruction”. In its earlier form, the ILR scale underscored five (primarily linguistic) traits: accent, comprehension, fluency, grammar and vocabulary. Later task (language functions), topic (content), and accuracy (on the five traits) became the three main criteria, and sociolinguistic ability was added to the traits to be assessed. A careful examination of the descriptors now reveals a close affinity with a theoretically-derived model of communicative language use such as the Canale & Swain (1980) model, with a particular emphasis on functional competence. While this context-embeddedness gives the ILR, ACTFL and similar frameworks a high degree of face validity, it also makes them very task specific." :::::In regards, to the question of the FSI validity? The FSI/ILR framework uses a structured interview format (Oral Proficiency Interview) along with standardized scoring criteria, and has a high degree of consistency in scoring across language testers. So, the FSI/ILR does pass a face test validity in practice. :::::The FSI/ILR point-of-view on language difficulty for English Speakers learning a new language, is one of close affinity with a theoretically-derived model of communicative language use such as the Canale & Swain (1980) model, with a particular emphasis on functional competence. :::::Overall, I feel this discussion should be broadened (not erased!), to include other competing points-of-view on the subject of language framework scales. Isn't the purpose of Wikipedia/Wikibooks to be inclusion of knowledge? Why not include all the different language framework scales from all parts of the world, and then have a discussion about each one's assumptions, goals, validity, evidence in support of, who uses which scale, et al. :::::In regards, to a criticism that Europe institutions do not acknowledge the FSI/ISL language framework scales. Actually, the Goethe-Institute has recently mentioned the similarities between it's own, [[Common European Framework of Reference for Languages: Learning, Teaching, Assessment (CEFR)]], which is the culmination of over 30 years of work done by the Council of Europe & the USA developed [[ACTFL Proficiency Guidelines]]. According to www.goethe.de [http://www.goethe.de/ins/us/lp/prj/ger/geu/enindex.htm] the Europeans are looking forward 'potential integration of the CEFR and ACTFL scales'. This supports the notion that the ACTFL and it's forefather language framework scales, the FSI/ISL have at the very least the attention of the members of the Council of Europe and its Language Policy Division in particular. —The preceding [[w:Wikipedia:Sign your posts on talk pages|unsigned]] comment was added by [[User:71.106.226.141|71.106.226.141]] ([[User talk:71.106.226.141|talk]] • [[Special:Contributions/71.106.226.141|contribs]]) 11:49, January 17, 2008. *'''Call to close''': this has been here for a month. If consensus has not been found yet, then I doubt prolongation will help. - [[User:Anonymous Dissident|Anonymous Dissident]][[User_talk:Anonymous Dissident|Talk]] 10:54, 21 January 2008 (UTC) |}
